ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Think deeply and organise thought process in sophisticated and ambivalent philosophical exegesis.
How to comprehend, analyze, and challenge philosophical texts

I definitely improved my reading skills in reading ancient Greek and Roman texts. I've never read any of these texts before, but I'm grateful for this program for letting me to engage with them intellectually. I do think of them quite often now. It pushed me out of my
comfort zone and definitely improved my analysis of these texts when reading them as a whole. My appreciation of classics and this time period has greatly improved. These really are foundational texts that I'm glad I read. The learning curve is very real and very intense (for me, coming from a magnet, STEM-oriented, public high school education) in terms of reading workload and essay writing and preparation, but there's a lot of support. The design of the program overall helped me with time management and reading/writing skills, all of which I am grateful for.
I learned how to synthesize philosophical proofs and deconstruct arguments.
I learned how to evaluate and construct arguments, as well as a deep understanding of the evolution of Ancient Western Philosophy
Ive grown significantly in my appreciation for philosophy more broadly. I feel much more competent attempting to decipher philosophical arguments.
Critical thinking, logical analysis, articulating arguments, knowledge of ancient Western philosophy
This was a great introductory ancient philosophy class that taught me how to think about philosophical questions and write papers in this disciplines somewhat-unique style.
How to read a primary text closely, how to follow the line of logic in complex philosophic arguments, how to reconstruct and evaluate views and present my own.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: very in depth discussion 
Weaknesses: not for those who do not comprehend the texts going into class

Strengths: well-organized, consistent workload, great feedback, sense of community with all
the seminars Weaknesses: sometimes ridiculous amount of reading, lack of historical
context/basic history of the time period when reading the books
We had a very large class, but Professor Harte managed it extremely well and made sure everyone felt comfortable contributing to discussions.

Strengths: Good syllabus, engaging and kind professor
Weaknesses: sometimes discussion would veer all over the place. Often no straight up lecture time where concepts were explained, we would just dive into discussion right away, as if everyone already understood everything

I had never taken a philosophy course prior to this class and was quite happy with it. That being said, it was more difficult than the other DS classes I took and sometimes I felt like there were too many ideas we were responsible to know but which we never talked about in class, thus meaning I didnt understand several of them. The volume of ideas was difficult to manage. I truly did enjoy this class though.

This course has diverse breadth and left me feeling like I understood the major traditions of thought at the time. I did feel like some sections were too dense for adequate in-class attention/explanation (particularly Aristotle)

Compared to other Directed Studies classes, the volume of reading is relatively more manageable, so it allows for greater close reading and, in turn, more specific seminar discussions. The reading can, at times, be complex, but it helps develop your reading comprehension skills.

The strengths were that the large course load challenged me to really be on top of my readings and papers. There was not a time where I didn't have things to work on or improve. The weakness may be a lack of step by step writing guidance (or even reading guidance). Especially in the beginning, it might have been more helpful if there was higher quality workshops on reading and writing philosophical texts on the section level (with the professor). It would have helped put everyone on more equal playing fields.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would, provided they had some background in philosophy already. Discussions tended away from basic principles and went straight towards analyzing the difficult parts.

Directed Studies overall is a self-selecting group of students, so if you're considering it or are
doing it, you are doing it for a reason that should motivate you to work hard and interact with
the texts and community as much as you can. I had extremely limited experience with these
texts coming it, but I wanted to try it out and overall I would recommend it. It is intense and
difficult but really rewarding: you get out of it as much as you put into it, and by design, this
course asks you to put a lot into it. It's a beautifully design liberal arts education, and I
guaranteed it's hard to regret doing it, even if it feels too difficult at times.
Absolutely! Professor Harte has been an incredible teacher and made the often very complex material feel approachable and understandable.
Yes. Definitely take this course if you are super into philosophy, Professor Harte is really incredible
Yes, this is a great introduction to philosophy as a discipline and tradition
Yes, it is a great introduction to ancient philosophy.

Yes, but only if you want a really in depth, rigorous introduction to ancient philosophy. Taking a seminar course with a very experienced professor is rewarding, but it is challenging and goes into the depths and nuances of the more general concepts/takeaways.
